pageData.text: In this investigation, you will study the phenomenon of refraction by measuring how a beam of laser light bends as it enters and exits a slab of transparent material. You will take careful geometric measurements and use <button class='glossary-text'>Snell’s law</button> of refraction to experimentally determine the index of refraction of light in the acrylic slab. This measurement will then be related to the speed of light in that material.

pageData.text: Cloaks of invisibility, in one form or another, are found in the ancient fairytales of cultures around the world. A certain invisibility cloak is even part of our contemporary pop culture. But what if scientists could make invisibility cloaks a reality? The science behind invisibility cloaks is about controlling the flow of light around an object. Researchers at Michigan Technological University discovered a novel way to manipulate <button class='glossary-text'>electromagnetic waves</button> and make objects appear invisible<sup>1</sup>. They used photonic crystals to bend the paths of light waves around an area to hide an object. The photonic crystals create a superluminal phase velocity (faster than the speed of light). This speed allows the light waves to curve past the object, thus making it appear invisible.

In 2019, Hyperstealth Technologies, a Canadian-based company, filed a patent for a “broadband invisibility cloak." Hyperstealth admits that its technology cloak is not perfect, however, they think it will be possible to hide not only people behind it but also military hardware. Militaries around the world are working to make invisibility cloaks for tanks, ships, and aircraft<sup>2</sup>.

1Semouchkina, E., Duan, R., Gandji, N.P., Jamilan, S., Semouchkin, G., and Pandey, R. (2016). Superluminal media formed by photonic crystals for transformation optics-based invisibility cloaks. Journal of Optics. 18 (4): 044007 DOI: 10.1088/2040-8978/18/4/044007

2Houser, K. (2019). Watch a real-life invisibility cloak designed for military use. The Byte.
https://futurism.com/the-byte/watch-invisibility-cloak-military-use

pageData.text: The speed of a wave is determined by the medium through which it travels, but this relationship is not always obvious or easy to predict. For example, sound travels faster in water than it does in air while light behaves the opposite way, traveling more slowly through water versus air. Without an easy theory to predict and understand the speed of waves through different media, we rely on experimentation, but this also seems challenging. Timing the transit of a fast-moving pulse through material is difficult to do with precision, but fortunately the speed of a wave has geometric consequences on the path it travels. Specifically, when a wave crosses the boundary from a faster to a slower medium, the direction of the wave’s propagation will bend—or refract—in a direction more closely aligned to the direction perpendicular to the interface between those two surfaces. Qualitatively, refraction is described by , or the law of refraction, which relates the speed of the wave in each medium to its angle measured with respect to the direction perpendicular to the surface:

pageData.text: Snell’s law can be proven using basic geometry and is exactly true for any type of waves, regardless of their speed or type. For , however, it is inconvenient to write the speed of light, which in vacuum is c = 299,792,458 m/s, so we will define an (n ) that expresses the speed of light in some material (v ) in terms of a fraction of the speed of light = c / n .
With this definition that Snell’s law states can be written as follows for light:

pageData.desc: Equation 2: n sub 1 sine theta sub 1 equals n sub 2 sine theta sub 2
pageData.altText: Equation 2: n sub 1 sine theta sub 1 equals n sub 2 sine theta sub 2

pageData.text: where θ1 is the angle of incidence, θ2 is the angle of refraction, and n 1 and n 2 are the respective indices of refraction of the materials (see Figure 1).

pageData.text: Now, for instance, a ray of sunshine that enters water (n 2 = 1.33) from air (n 1 = 1.00) at an incident angle of θ1 = 40.0 degrees will bend to an angle of θ2 = 28.9 degrees. Check this by solving Snell’s law and remembering to calculate in degrees instead of radians. You have probably observed this obvious distortion of images above and below the surface of a body of water many times in your life. Now you will see how to use Snell’s law to use the phenomenon to calculate the speed of light.

pageData.question: What would it mean if a material had an index of refraction that was smaller than 1?

options.text: Light would move faster in this (therefore fictitious) material than it does in a vacuum.
Light would move more slowly in this material than in a vacuum.
A light beam entering this material from air/space would bend toward the line perpendicular to the surface.
A light beam entering this material from air/space would be completely reflected.
Light would move at the speed of light in this material.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The index of refraction is calculated by (speed of light in vacuum)/(speed of light in material). This ratio can only be less than 1 if the speed of light in the material is faster than the speed of light in a vacuum.

assestmentData.question: What does the index of refraction have to do with the speed of light in a material?

options.text: The index of refraction is the ratio of the speed of light in that material to the speed of light in a vacuum.

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will shine a laser pointer through an acrylic slab, measure the angle of incidence and angle of refraction, and use this data to calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>index of refraction</button> and speed of light for the acrylic block.

typeBefore.title:

 Determining the Index of Refraction of Light (19 steps)

pageData.text: Lay a sheet of blank white or graph paper over the cardboard sheet so they are in the same orientation. Use tape to attach the paper to the cardboard at each corner.
Lay the acrylic slab broadside down on center of the paper. The long edge of the slab should parallel the long edge of the paper and cardboard.
Place the laser pointer on the paper facing one of the long, thin sides of the slab such that the laser is perpendicular to and centered on the length of the slab.

Without moving the acrylic slab, use a pen or pencil to trace the long edges of the slab (where the laser beam will enter and leave the slab). These lines correspond to the line marked “Surface” in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: An incident ray entering a surface showing the angles of the reflected ray above and the refracted ray below the surface.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: An incident ray entering a surface showing the angles of the reflected ray above and the refracted ray below the surface.

pageData.text: Turn on the laser pointer. Use the protractor to adjust the position of the laser beam (incidence ray) and create an incidence angle of 15 degrees relative to its original position (see Figure 1). Note that although there are several beams created by the passage of the laser beam through the acrylic slab, only one refracted beam passes through the slab as shown in Figure 2.
Note: The laser pointer will remain on and must be stationary for the duration of the investigation. Use books or other items on hand to support the laser pointer if necessary.

pageData.text: Use a pen or pencil to mark the points at which the laser beam enters and exits the acrylic slab on the surface lines drawn in Step 4. If the beam is not visible in the acrylic, hold the straight pin vertically and move it along each edge of the slab until the pin interrupts the laser light. Poke a small hole in the paper on each surface line to mark these locations as shown in Figure 3.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Holding the pin vertically to mark interruptions in laser light
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Holding the pin vertically to mark interruptions in laser light

pageData.text: Use a pen or pencil to mark a third point along the laser beam (incidence ray) near where the beam leaves the laser.

Remove the slab from the paper. Use a straight edge, such as a ruler, to draw a line between the point where the beam exited the laser pointer and the point where the beam entered the slab. This line is the incidence ray (see Figure 1).
Draw a second line between the point where the beam entered the slab and the point where the beam exited the slab. This line represents the refracted ray (see Figure 1).

Draw a third line from the point where the beam entered the slab to the closest edge of the paper such that the line is drawn perpendicular to the surface line. To distinguish this line from the rays drawn earlier, use a different colored pen or pencil. This line is known as the normal.

Use the protractor to measure the incident and refracted angles from the normal. Record the degrees of each angle for Trial 1 in Data Table 1. Label the incident angle “θ1” and the refracted angle “θ2” on the sheet of paper.
Carefully remove the paper from the cardboard sheet.
Repeat Steps 1–13 for each of four additional trials. Increase the incidence angle created in Step 5 by 15 degrees with each trial.
Take a photograph of the labeled sheet of paper from one of the trials.

pageData.text: Calculate the refractive index of acrylic.

Calculate the speed of light through acrylic. Before moving on, a good way to check your data is to solve for the of acrylic algebraically to verify that it is a reasonable value. Pick one pair of angles from your data and solve for n 2 for that particular data point.
1.00 sin θ1 = n 2 sin θ2

If your value is less than 1, you might be measuring the angles from parallel instead of perpendicular to the surface. If your value is very close to 1, you might be measuring both angles in air instead of air and acrylic or not using large enough incident angles. If your value is somewhere between 1 and 2, your data was probably taken correctly and you can proceed to Part B, where you will use graphical methods to find a better value of the index of refraction for acrylic.

To find the experimental value of the acrylic slab’s , you will use a best-fit line. The data and , however, are not obviously in the form of a linear equation (y = mx + b). This happens frequently in experiments, and you will have to choose and calculate different quantities to get a linear graph.Notice what happens if you identify x = sin⁡ θ2 (that is, plot sin⁡ θ2 along the x-axis) and y = n1 sin θ1 (that is plot n1 sin⁡ θ1 along the y-axis). Consider the following questions:
  • What sort of graph will you see?
  • What do you expect the slope of this graph to be?
  • What do you expect the y-intercept of this graph to be?
Fill in these quantities in Data Table 1, and plot your results using plotting software that allows you to find a best-fit line.

pageData.text: Ask yourself, is your value of the line’s slope a reasonable value for the index of refraction for acrylic? Is the y-intercept of your line close to the expected value of zero? Use the definition of the index of refraction and the speed of light in vacuum to calculate your measured value of the speed of light in acrylic.

In Activity 2, you will use the acrylic block to compare the calculated and observed critical angles and observe how different colors of light are refracted. You will then use a simulation to determine the critical angles for different materials.

With the acrylic slab in the same position as in Activity 1, is it possible to have the laser beam enter one side of the acrylic slab and exit an adjacent side (i.e., enter from the left side and exit out the top) rather than exit the opposite side (i.e., exit out the right side)? Adjust the position of the laser beam to explore this phenomenon.This phenomenon is called total internal reflection, which can be understood by looking at what says about a light ray leaving a medium in which light travels more slowly. The maximum value that either the incident or refracted angle can take at the surface is 90 degrees. When light goes from a slow to a fast medium, like leaving acrylic into air, the largest incident angle for which refraction out of the medium is possible is called the critical angle. For incident angles greater than the critical angle, reflection— not refraction—occurs at the surface. Trying to refract a ray at an angle greater than 90 degrees is not possible.

Solve Snell’s law to find the critical angle for acrylic using the <button class='glossary-text'>index of refraction</button> for acrylic calculated in Activity 1. Record your calculations in the Lab Notebook.
nacrylic sin θcricital = 1.00 sin 90°

Use the techniques from Activity 1 to experimentally determine the critical angle of the acrylic slab. Compare the experimental critical angle to the critical angle calculated by solving the equation for Snell’s law using an angle of refraction of 90 degrees. Record the critical angle value in the Lab Notebook.

To explore dispersion, the dependence of the refractive index on color, in optical materials, first construct a beam of white light. You can do this by shining a small flashlight or the LED light on a phone through a slit cut into a cardboard box. Place the white light up against the slit and slowly move the light away until a tightly collimated beam of white light shines through (see Figure 4). The characteristic of a collimated beam of white light is the radius of the light and should be relatively consistent from one end of the beam to the other.

Place the acrylic slab in front of the white light beam and experiment with different geometries:
  • Adjust the incidence angle.
  • Change the side of the slab from which the beam exits (opposite versus adjacent).

Compare the appearance of the beam as it leaves the slab to the appearance of the laser beam as it left the slab in Activity 1. Use your observations to:
  • Describe refraction indices for different colors of light
  • Describe how the speed of red light in acrylic compares to the speed of blue light through the same medium
